content: Astronomia Solar is its name, and it is the first of it's kind, it was engineered by the expert watchmakers - Jocob & Co.This luxury watch sells for $400,000 per piece and there are only 25 pieces of them that will ever be available, it was made to be just as scarce as Bitcoin is.Quote from: https://bitcoinist.com/bitcoin-designed-watch-sells-for-400000/Being a limited-edition timepiece, the Astronomia symbolizes the early beginnings of Bitcoin and how it evolved from being a theory to becoming a pivotal building block of today’s financial system.Such concept also adds to its overall appeal to investors and traders who have the wherewithal to shell out a stupid amount of dough to satisfy their needs.Noticeably, the 444 components and two rotating prongs of the Astronomia are eye-catching. The first platform consists of the microchip main plate which resembles that of the brain of Satoshi Nakamoto and the other is composed of its arms as well as other intricate moving parts.The watch is able to complete a rotation for 10 minutes which is in fact the time you need to clock in when waiting for changes in Bitcoin price. The clock dial looks the same with the motherboard fan found in ASICs that mine BTC.The hands of this black Astronomia Bitcoin watch is made of 18K rose gold.So guys, what do you think?, if you have the money, will you splash $400,000 to acquire this timepiece, or are you letting it pass?, let's discuss. Find out more about this amazing timepiece from quoted link above.

comments.body: Truth be told, even the big bag holders who acquire this kind of metal piece are all with the mindset of an investment. What I was looking out for in the article is to find out how many karat golds the watch is made up of, because most smart people that wear  this type of expensive jewelry are with the investment mindset that is their can resale the watch x 10 of the amount they bought it in the next few years just like Bitcoin, spending 100k to own a Bitcoin is never a stupid idea rather the wisest and smartest idea so the article referring to spending $400,000 as stupid money is wrong unless the watch has no investment value attached to it which I doubt that even though the article does not mention how many cubics of gold is embedded in the watch.
